title: Appalling Customer Service
main_comment: If you can, avoid shopping with Gap online from Austalia. Western Australia doesn't have a Gap store so my only option was ordering goods from the US (even after phoning the Melbourne store but they wouldn't post). The shipping of two pairs of girls shorts cost $42, almost as much as the shorts alone were worth. After a week, I inquired about the shipping advice (given I hadn't received a dispatch confirmation) only to be told that the goods had already been delivered. The problem was that I was in Australia and the goods had been delivered to somewhere in Illinois, US. After corresponding with Gap and asking them to resend the goods but expedite the shipping, given I had lost a week from the original timeline, I was advised post-shipment that the original timeline of the order had been extended and that they may take between 2.5 to 5 weeks to arrive, not counting the week lost from the incorrect delivery. The original advice communicated from Gap in the sales transaction was 2-4 weeks. Gap customer service was at best ambivalent, seemingly wanting to shift responsibility to Borderfree. When paying A$42 for shipping for a package of probably less than 1kg, I expect better service, as I can imagine, would others. Additionally, after further correspondence with Gap's customer service, they stated that if I was unhappy with their online ordering that I could set up a US address and ship there. It's quite stunning really that a company like Gap would offer this as an alternative rather than improving global business and addressing deficiencies in their point to point shipping. Put simply, avoid shopping online at Gap from Australia until they actually start to listen to customers. Until then, they are only paying lip service about customer service and overcharging overseas customers with exorbitant shipping rates.

title: Poor customer service, your online delivery people made a mistake and I have to pay for it?

We got to the store, but only one plaid Henley shirt was there in XL, not my size. However, I did find the flair out pants. My mom had liked a silk shirt I showed her online, but it also wasn't in store because it was a new style. My mistake, to look online and expect to find it in store. So, we bought the things we could in store, and the cashier ordered the silk shirt and plaid henley, both in medium, through Gap.com. Three weeks later, the package arrives (it took a while), inside was the silk shirt, but instead of the Henley shirt, there is a pair of leggings with a label on it saying it is the plaid Henley. I research online to see which store in Colorado might have the plaid Henley in the right color and size medium. Unfortunately, shirt is sold out online in s, m, and l. The only store that has the right shirt style is in Aurora, 45 minutes away from my house. I put on hold the Medium and Large, the medium was in the wrong color but i was trying it for size, my last resort if the large didn't work being to have my sister in NY get it, which would be complicated because it's an exchange and not just a purchase. Finally, i get to Gap in Aurora and decide the Large is ok. But, because the plastic was labeled as plaid henley and had leggings in it, they said I could not just give them the leggings in exchange for the shirt. The whole process took at least 30 minutes, mostly the employee was getting instructions from a lady on the phone. My review is not against the Gap employees at this store, but rather the lady who was on the phone and Gap.com. Anyways, I didn't just walk out with the plaid Henley (already paid for mind you), I had to pay for the shirt and then now have to ship the leggings to Gap and wait 7 days to be refunded for the shirt. It was so complicated and I have to to all this extra work now. Hopefully I will even be refunded correctly because the receipt from paying today said the tax was 8%, whereas the invoice from online (what was paid before) says 4.25%. What I paid for the plaid Henley was also 50 cents more than the original purchase. So basically, I may be out just a couple dollars, which is ok, but annoying, gas, and time spent. Not much, but it's a lot when it wasn't my mistake and they still make me pay for THEIR mistake. I don't even want this shirt that bad anymore, it didn't fit that nicely because my boobs are too big for it and so the large fit better for that reason, but is wider than would be most flattering. Whatever, I'm ok with that though. Nevertheless, I'm never shopping at Gap or any affiliate stores again because this experience was so annoying and I think their clothes are boring (At Gap).I honestly don't want anything from Gap, like restitution, but they just better refund me correctly. Originally I paid 35.80 for the shirt (cheaper since we used gap cash) but today I paid 37.75 because the shirt cost more and the tax was double. So which will they refund me? The ladies at the store said they'll refund the invoice which is less than what I paid today. Why am I paying for your mistake??
